qas.question: A treaty that puts all of its obligations in action simply by becoming a party to it is known as what?
What do non-self-executing treaties typically require from a party to enable it to fulfill its obligations?
What is "implementing legislation" that is required by a party to a treaty to enable it to fulfill its obligations under the treaty?

answers.text: a change in the domestic law of a state party

qas.question: A treaty requiring local prosecution by a party for particular crimes is an example of which type of treaty?
Signing a self-executing treaty automatically does what for a party?

answers.text: puts the treaty and all of its obligations in action

context: Treaties may be seen as '<a0_0>self-executing<a0_0/>', in that merely becoming a party <a4_0>puts the treaty and all of its obligations in action<a4_0/>. Other treaties may be <a3_0>non-self-executing<a3_0/> and require '<a1_0>implementing legislation<a1_0/>'—<a2_0>a change in the domestic law of a state party<a2_0/> that will direct or enable it to fulfill treaty obligations. An example of a treaty requiring such legislation would be one mandating local prosecution by a party for particular crimes.
